hints.content:
The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is the number of equal parts being counted.

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is the number of equal parts in **one** whole. 

$\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{numerator}}}{\blueD{\text{denominator}}}$

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is $\blueD3$, so we need $\blueD3$ equal pieces in each whole.

The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is $\purpleD{6}$, so we need $\purpleD6$ equal parts shaded.

The following images show $\dfrac63$ shaded:


[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: Three squares. Each square is divided into 3 equal parts. The first square has 2 parts shaded. The second square has 3 parts shaded. The third square has 1 part shaded. !
Two squares. Each square is divided into 3 equal parts. Each square has 3 parts shaded. !

question.content:
Each large square represents $1$ whole.

**Which images show $\dfrac63$ shaded?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

choices.content: ![One square, divided into 6 parts. Three parts are shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/bd2a607fe05b3d80284bc78646cc71731de38893)

![Three squares. Each square is divided into 3 equal parts. The first square has 2 parts shaded. The second square has 3 parts shaded. The third square has 1 part shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/2c0ea8d3925b0e9eae054cc05d5d8e7bfae9e76e)

![Two squares. Each square is divided into 6 equal parts. The first square has 2 parts shaded. The second square has 1 part shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/75259ed44a4cd19bbd4de3e80546b31c18326873)
![Two squares. Each square is divided into 3 equal parts. Each square has 3 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5f9f09baf4d5588ff449b3476631402602166433)
